Probabilistic Heuristics for Disseminating Information in Networks

AlexandreÂ O.Â Stauffer
ValmirÂ C.Â Barbosa

Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro
Programa de Engenharia de Sistemas e ComputaÃ§Ã£o, COPPE

21941-972 Rio de Janeiro - RJ, Brazil Corresponding author (valmir@cos.ufrj.br).
Abstract

We study the problem of disseminating a piece of information through all the nodes of a network, given that it is known originally only to a single node. In the absence of any structural knowledge on the network other than the nodesâ€™ neighborhoods, this problem is traditionally solved by flooding all the networkâ€™s edges. We analyze a recently introduced probabilistic algorithm for flooding and give an alternative probabilistic heuristic that can lead to some cost-effective improvements, like better trade-offs between the message and time complexities involved. We analyze the two algorithms both mathematically and by means of simulations, always within a random-graph framework and considering relevant node-degree distributions.


Keywords: Random networks, Probabilistic flooding, Heuristic flooding.

1 Introduction

A network can be viewed as an undirected graph G=(NG,EG)ğºsubscriptğ‘ğºsubscriptğ¸ğºG=(N_{G},E_{G})italic_G = ( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) with n=|NG|ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğºn=|N_{G}|italic_n = | italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | nodes and m=|EG|ğ‘šsubscriptğ¸ğºm=|E_{G}|italic_m = | italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | edges, in which the existence of an edge (u,v)ğ‘¢ğ‘£\left(u,v\right)( italic_u , italic_v ) represents the possibility of bidirectional communication between nodes uğ‘¢uitalic_u and vğ‘£vitalic_v. We consider the problem of disseminating a piece of information, referred to as Iğ¼Iitalic_I, to all the nodes of the network, given that initially only one node, called the originator, has it.

A traditional algorithm to disseminate information in networks when nodes know their immediate neighborhoods and nothing else is what we call uninformed flooding [16], in allusion to the fact that its actions do in no way take into account the structure of the network or any of its properties. In this algorithm, the originator starts by sending Iğ¼Iitalic_I to its neighbors; when receiving Iğ¼Iitalic_I for the first time, each of the other nodes forwards it to its own neighbors. This algorithm has message complexity of Î˜â¢(m)Î˜ğ‘š\Theta(m)roman_Î˜ ( italic_m ), as exactly two messages are transmitted on each edge, and worst-case time complexity of Oâ¢(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n)italic_O ( italic_n ), the latter related to the customary message-passing causal chains of distributed computing under full asynchronism [3]. Also, when edges can be assumed to have approximately equal delays associated with them, the algorithmâ€™s average waiting time, which is the average time for a node to receive Iğ¼Iitalic_I, is given by the average distance from the originator in the network, that is, the average number of edges on the shortest paths between the originator and each of the other nodes.

Our interest in this paper is to study the trade-off between the message complexity and the average waiting time when Iğ¼Iitalic_I is no longer forwarded deterministically to all of a nodeâ€™s neighbors, but rather is sent as the result of probabilistic decisions. Our initial motivation has been the recent introduction of probabilistic flooding [2], which prescribes for each node that it forward Iğ¼Iitalic_I to each of its neighbors with fixed probability pğ‘pitalic_p. Probabilistic flooding is then also â€œuninformed,â€ constituting essentially a simple stochastic generalization of the aforementioned (deterministic) uninformed flooding. We introduce in SectionÂ 2 the alternative that we call heuristic flooding, which is also probabilistic in nature but, unlike probabilistic flooding, takes the networkâ€™s structure into account insofar as it can be inferred from the nodesâ€™ immediate neighborhoods.

Naturally, flooding the network with copies of Iğ¼Iitalic_I that are propagated probabilistically does not ensure that all nodes will eventually receive a copy. There do exist applications, however, that may benefit from the aforementioned trade-off even in the absence of such delivery guarantees. We refer the reader to [2] and to the references therein for examples in the area of peer-to-peer computing when Iğ¼Iitalic_I is interpreted as a query and the flooding as a search.

We base our analyses of both algorithms on the generating functions of discrete probability distributions [10]. The formalism we utilize is the one laid down in [15], whose details are briefly reviewed and extended in SectionÂ 3. Our analyses are also based on what we call a flooding digraph, which is a random directed subgraph of the network. In SectionÂ 4, we introduce this subgraph and use it to obtain our analytical results.

All our analyses are carried out in the framework of random graphs [1]. Within this framework, we give special attention to random graphs whose node degrees are either Poisson-distributed or distributed according to a power law. The former arise in the classic context of ErdÅ‘s and RÃ©nyi [7], while the latter have recently been found to be representative of networks like the Internet and the WWW [8, 12, 1]. Simulation results are given in Section 5 for these models of random graphs.

A comparative study of the two probabilistic approaches is given in SectionÂ 6, and concluding remarks in SectionÂ 7.

2 Heuristic flooding

In probabilistic flooding, each node decides whether to send Iğ¼Iitalic_I to each of its neighbors based on a fixed probability parameter pğ‘pitalic_p. As a consequence, a node with a small degree has a smaller probability of receiving the information than a node with a large degree. Given a node uğ‘¢uitalic_u and one of its neighbors vğ‘£vitalic_v, if ağ‘aitalic_a is the degree of uğ‘¢uitalic_u and bğ‘bitalic_b the degree of vğ‘£vitalic_v, our new heuristic flooding is based on a function hâ¢(a,b)â„ğ‘ğ‘h(a,b)italic_h ( italic_a , italic_b ) representing the probability that node uğ‘¢uitalic_u sends Iğ¼Iitalic_I to node vğ‘£vitalic_v. Intuitively, hâ¢(a,b)â„ğ‘ğ‘h(a,b)italic_h ( italic_a , italic_b ) is expected to have a larger value when at least one of ağ‘aitalic_a and bğ‘bitalic_b is small than when they are both large, thus attempting to compensate for the inherent drawback of probabilistic flooding that we just mentioned, and also to reflect the understanding that a small ağ‘aitalic_a may signify the existence of insufficient alternative routes for vğ‘£vitalic_v to ultimately receive Iğ¼Iitalic_I from uğ‘¢uitalic_u even when bğ‘bitalic_b is large.

Ideally, an accurate heuristic function would require some knowledge about the topology of the network beyond the nodesâ€™ immediate neighborhoods; realistically, however, a node can only be assumed to have information about its own neighbors. For this reason, heuristic flooding is defined to operate under the assumption by each node uğ‘¢uitalic_u that a neighboring node vğ‘£vitalic_v can only receive the information from minâ¡{a,b}ğ‘ğ‘\min\left\{a,b\right\}roman_min { italic_a , italic_b } of vğ‘£vitalic_vâ€™s own neighbors, for each one with equal probability hâ¢(a,b)â„ğ‘ğ‘h(a,b)italic_h ( italic_a , italic_b ), where ağ‘aitalic_a and bğ‘bitalic_b are the degrees of uğ‘¢uitalic_u and vğ‘£vitalic_v, respectively. In other words, there are two sides to our assumption. One side is that, if uğ‘¢uitalic_u decides not to forward Iğ¼Iitalic_I to vğ‘£vitalic_v, then vğ‘£vitalic_v can still receive Iğ¼Iitalic_I from minâ¡{a,b}âˆ’1ğ‘ğ‘1\min\left\{a,b\right\}-1roman_min { italic_a , italic_b } - 1 of its neighbors, if any, in each case with the same probability hâ¢(a,b)â„ğ‘ğ‘h(a,b)italic_h ( italic_a , italic_b ). The other side of the assumption is that the other bâˆ’minâ¡{a,b}ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘b-\min\left\{a,b\right\}italic_b - roman_min { italic_a , italic_b } neighbors of vğ‘£vitalic_v, if any, are unable to receive Iğ¼Iitalic_I if vğ‘£vitalic_v does not send it to them.

This heuristic function has the property that, when both ağ‘aitalic_a and bğ‘bitalic_b are large, hâ¢(a,b)â„ğ‘ğ‘h(a,b)italic_h ( italic_a , italic_b ) is small, which corresponds to the intuition that there may exist other paths along which vğ‘£vitalic_v can receive Iğ¼Iitalic_I, so it may not be essential that uğ‘¢uitalic_u sends it to vğ‘£vitalic_v. 4 Mathematical analysis

We start by considering a generic probabilistic algorithm for disseminating a piece of information Iğ¼Iitalic_I on the network represented by GğºGitalic_G. In this algorithm, when a node of degree ağ‘aitalic_a receives Iğ¼Iitalic_I for the first time, it forwards Iğ¼Iitalic_I to each of its neighbors with probability fâ¢(a,b)ğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘f(a,b)italic_f ( italic_a , italic_b ), where bğ‘bitalic_b is the degree of the prospective recipient. This process induces the appearance of a random directed subgraph F=(NF,EF)ğ¹subscriptğ‘ğ¹subscriptğ¸ğ¹F=(N_{F},E_{F})italic_F = ( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of GğºGitalic_G that we call the flooding digraph. This digraph has the same nodes as GğºGitalic_G (that is, VF=VGsubscriptğ‘‰ğ¹subscriptğ‘‰ğºV_{F}=V_{G}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and its edges are such that, for (u,v)âˆˆEGğ‘¢ğ‘£subscriptğ¸ğº(u,v)\in E_{G}( italic_u , italic_v ) âˆˆ italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the directed edge (uâ†’v)â†’ğ‘¢ğ‘£(u\to v)( italic_u â†’ italic_v ) exists in EFsubscriptğ¸ğ¹E_{F}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with probability fâ¢(a,b)ğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘f(a,b)italic_f ( italic_a , italic_b ), given that ağ‘aitalic_a and bğ‘bitalic_b are the degrees of nodes uğ‘¢uitalic_u and vğ‘£vitalic_v in GğºGitalic_G, respectively.

Clearly, this generic algorithm can stand for both probabilistic flooding and heuristic flooding. In the former case, fâ¢(a,b)=pğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘f(a,b)=pitalic_f ( italic_a , italic_b ) = italic_p regardless of ağ‘aitalic_a or bğ‘bitalic_b; in the latter, fâ¢(a,b)ğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘f(a,b)italic_f ( italic_a , italic_b ) is the heuristic function hâ¢(a,b)â„ğ‘ğ‘h(a,b)italic_h ( italic_a , italic_b ) given by (2). As probabilistic flooding is a special case of heuristic flooding, for the remainder of this section we concentrate solely on the latter and use the hâ¢(a,b)â„ğ‘ğ‘h(a,b)italic_h ( italic_a , italic_b ) of (2) instead of fâ¢(a,b)ğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘f(a,b)italic_f ( italic_a , italic_b ).

4.1 Random digraphs

Let us first review some of the properties of random digraphs in general and also how they apply to the case of Fğ¹Fitalic_F.

For uğ‘¢uitalic_u a node of a digraph, its in-neighbors are those nodes from which an edge exists directed toward uğ‘¢uitalic_u; its out-neighbors are those nodes toward which an edge exists directed from uğ‘¢uitalic_u. Moreover, a node is an rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-in-neighbor of uğ‘¢uitalic_u if the directed distance from it to uğ‘¢uitalic_u is rğ‘Ÿritalic_r. Similarly, a node is an rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-out-neighbor of uğ‘¢uitalic_u if the directed distance from uğ‘¢uitalic_u to it is rğ‘Ÿritalic_r. When a directed path exists from node uğ‘¢uitalic_u to node vğ‘£vitalic_v, we say that vğ‘£vitalic_v is reachable from uğ‘¢uitalic_u (equivalently, uğ‘¢uitalic_u reaches vğ‘£vitalic_v).

A connected component of the undirected graph that underlies a digraph (i.e., the graph that we obtain when edge directions are ignored) is called a weakly connected component of the digraph. Thus a digraph has a size-Î˜â¢(n)Î˜ğ‘›\Theta(n)roman_Î˜ ( italic_n ) weakly connected component, referred to as the giant weakly connected component (GWCC), if and only if the undirected graph that underlies it has a GCC.

The GWCC of a digraph has four distinguished types of sub-digraphs. In the case of Fğ¹Fitalic_F, they are as illustrated in FigureÂ 2 and such that:

  • â€¢

    The giant strongly connected component (GSCC) is the largest sub-digraph of the GWCC that is maximal with respect to the property that any of its nodes is reachable from any other.

  • â€¢

    The giant in-component (GIN), comprising a fraction Î¸Finsubscriptsuperscriptğœƒinğ¹\theta^{\textrm{in}}_{F}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the nodes of GğºGitalic_G (or a fraction Î¸Fin/Î¸Gsubscriptsuperscriptğœƒinğ¹subscriptğœƒğº\theta^{\textrm{in}}_{F}/\theta_{G}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the nodes of the GCC of GğºGitalic_G), contains all the nodes that can reach the GSCC (including, by definition, those of the GSCC).

  • â€¢

    The giant out-component (GOUT), comprising a fraction Î¸Foutsubscriptsuperscriptğœƒoutğ¹\theta^{\textrm{out}}_{F}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the nodes of GğºGitalic_G (or a fraction Î¸Fout/Î¸Gsubscriptsuperscriptğœƒoutğ¹subscriptğœƒğº\theta^{\textrm{out}}_{F}/\theta_{G}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the nodes of the GCC of GğºGitalic_G), contains all the nodes that are reachable from the GSCC (including, by definition, those of the GSCC).

  • â€¢

    Each of the so-called tendrils consists of some of the remaining nodes [6].

4.2 Number of nodes reached

We now consider the expected fraction of nodes of GğºGitalic_G that receive Iğ¼Iitalic_I in heuristic flooding. Recall that, by assumption, GğºGitalic_G almost surely has a GCC and the originator is one of the nodes of the GCC. Two cases must be considered. The first case corresponds to the originator being outside the GIN, belonging therefore either to the portion of the GOUT that does not intersect the GSCC or to a tendril. This case happens with probability 1âˆ’Î¸Fin/Î¸G1subscriptsuperscriptğœƒinğ¹subscriptğœƒğº1-\theta^{\textrm{in}}_{F}/\theta_{G}1 - italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and leads to a negligibly small number of nodes reached by the flooding. The second case is the case in which the originator is inside the GIN. It occurs with probability Î¸Fin/Î¸Gsubscriptsuperscriptğœƒinğ¹subscriptğœƒğº\theta^{\textrm{in}}_{F}/\theta_{G}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the flooding necessarily reaches all the nodes of the GOUT. 4.4 Average waiting time

As we mentioned in SectionÂ 1, assessing a distributed algorithmâ€™s time-related complexities in a fully general asynchronous setting requires that message-passing causal chains be considered [3]. In our current context, and taking into account our current knowledge of random graphs and their analysis, obtaining accurate analytical estimates of those complexities for flooding seems infeasible. Our choice is then to settle for a less general form of asynchronism in which the delay associated with the delivery of a message over an edge of GğºGitalic_G is roughly constant for all of GğºGitalic_Gâ€™s edges. In this case, the waiting time before a node is reached by a flooding can be taken to be proportional to the distance in GğºGitalic_G from the originator to that node.

Recall that, even though we employ the common denomination as a path, in the case of Fğ¹Fitalic_F paths are directed, while in GğºGitalic_G they are undirected.

5 Simulation results

In our simulations we have used random graphs as models for networks [1]. The network may thus not be connected, so simulations have only been carried out inside the largest connected component of the random graph. Also, in order to ensure that such a component encompasses a large number of nodes, we have restricted ourselves to graphs for which a GCC is almost surely guaranteed to exist. Our interest has been to analyze Pnsubscriptğ‘ƒnP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Pmsubscriptğ‘ƒmP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Ptsubscriptğ‘ƒtP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and to this end we have simulated probabilistic flooding for p=0.30ğ‘0.30p=0.30italic_p = 0.30, 0.600.600.600.60, 0.900.900.900.90 and heuristic flooding for Î±=0.90ğ›¼0.90\alpha=0.90italic_Î± = 0.90, 0.950.950.950.95, 0.990.990.990.99.

We have considered two random-graph models. In the first model GğºGitalic_G is generated on nğ‘›nitalic_n nodes by creating an edge between any two distinct nodes with fixed probability z/(nâˆ’1)ğ‘§ğ‘›1z/(n-1)italic_z / ( italic_n - 1 ) for suitable zğ‘§zitalic_z. A node in the resulting graph has degree ağ‘aitalic_a with the Poisson probability of mean zğ‘§zitalic_z [4], that is, PGâ¢(a)=eâˆ’zâ¢za/a!subscriptğ‘ƒğºğ‘superscriptğ‘’ğ‘§superscriptğ‘§ğ‘ğ‘P_{G}(a)=e^{-z}z^{a}/a!italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a ) = italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_z end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_a !. Also, we have ZG=zsubscriptğ‘ğºğ‘§Z_{G}=zitalic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_z and âŸ¨KG2âŸ©=z2+zdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptsubscriptğ¾ğº2superscriptğ‘§2ğ‘§\left<K_{G}^{2}\right>=z^{2}+zâŸ¨ italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© = italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_z, which by (6) implies that we need z>1ğ‘§1z>1italic_z > 1 for the GCC to almost surely exist.

FigureÂ 3 shows the results obtained by simulating probabilistic and heuristic flooding on random graphs with Poisson-distributed degrees for n=10000ğ‘›10000n=10000italic_n = 10000 and zğ‘§zitalic_z varying from 1111 to 10101010. For each value of zğ‘§zitalic_z, the simulation consisted of generating 15151515 random graphs and, for each one, doing 1000100010001000 instances of each type of flooding (uninformed, probabilistic, and heuristic), each from a randomly chosen node inside the GCC. The simulation results are given as averages of Pnsubscriptğ‘ƒnP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Pmsubscriptğ‘ƒmP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Ptsubscriptğ‘ƒtP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over the 15000 samples. Notice first of all that agreement between simulation and analytical results is very good throughout, with a slight deviation only in parts (c) and (f) of the figure. Such deviations are attributed to the various approximations of SectionÂ 4.4. Note also that both probabilistic and heuristic flooding do indeed improve on uninformed flooding as far as the number of messages used is concerned (Pm<1subscriptğ‘ƒm1P_{\textrm{m}}<1italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1), but nearly always at the expense of larger waiting times (Pt>1subscriptğ‘ƒt1P_{\textrm{t}}>1italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 1).

The results for probabilistic flooding (FigureÂ 3(aâ€“c)) show that, given a value of pğ‘pitalic_p, there exists a value of zğ‘§zitalic_z above which nearly all the nodes of the network are reached by the flooding. If we require Pnâ‰¥0.99subscriptğ‘ƒn0.99P_{\textrm{n}}\geq 0.99italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0.99, then the threshold values for zğ‘§zitalic_z are z=5ğ‘§5z=5italic_z = 5 for p=0.90ğ‘0.90p=0.90italic_p = 0.90 and z=9ğ‘§9z=9italic_z = 9 for p=0.60ğ‘0.60p=0.60italic_p = 0.60. For p=0.30ğ‘0.30p=0.30italic_p = 0.30 the threshold is greater than 10101010. The plots for Pmsubscriptğ‘ƒmP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT show that Pmsubscriptğ‘ƒmP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT increases with zğ‘§zitalic_z roughly until these thresholds are reached, remaining constant and approximately equal to pğ‘pitalic_p from there onward. The plots for Ptsubscriptğ‘ƒtP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT show a similar but not identical behavior: like Pmsubscriptğ‘ƒmP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Ptsubscriptğ‘ƒtP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT often increases roughly until the thresholds are reached; unlike Pmsubscriptğ‘ƒmP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Ptsubscriptğ‘ƒtP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT starts to decrease slightly as zğ‘§zitalic_z is further increased onward. All the plots show that Pnsubscriptğ‘ƒnP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Pmsubscriptğ‘ƒmP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Ptsubscriptğ‘ƒtP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT have value 00 when zğ‘§zitalic_z is near 1111. In contrast, Ptsubscriptğ‘ƒtP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT increases onward through the higher values of zğ‘§zitalic_z. Generation of a random graph with degrees thus distributed can be achieved in two phases. This algorithm clearly generates a multigraph (a graph in which multiple edges and self-loops are allowed to exist), but the resulting graph is consistent with the model used in our analysis, where we assumed edge independence throughout. Furthermore, even though there are other algorithms to generate random graphs with a given degree sequence [13, 9], it is still unclear how to use them within reasonable time bounds. The fact that multiple edges or self-loops may now exist in GğºGitalic_G has direct impact on how the various flooding algorithms are simulated. Specifically, a node no longer considers whether to forward the information it receives for the first time to each of its neighbors, but rather whether to forward it on each of the edges that are incident to it in GğºGitalic_G.

6 Probabilistic versus heuristic flooding

In spite of having already obtained results on both types of flooding, we still cannot compare them to each other directly, as the parameter pğ‘pitalic_p of probabilistic flooding has no relation whatsoever to the parameter Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± of heuristic flooding. In this section, our strategy to make such a comparison possible is to first simulate heuristic flooding with Î±=0.99ğ›¼0.99\alpha=0.99italic_Î± = 0.99 and then use the resulting value of Pnsubscriptğ‘ƒnP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to obtain, via (23), the value of pğ‘pitalic_p for which probabilistic flooding is expected to reach the same fraction of the graphâ€™s nodes.

Our results under this strategy are shown in FigureÂ 5 for the Poisson case. Notice, first, that the strategy seems indeed to be effective, since the plots for Pnsubscriptğ‘ƒnP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are practically the same for both types of flooding. For zğ‘§zitalic_z right past 1111, all the six plots exhibit an anomaly, which is once again likely due to the fact that, at these values of zğ‘§zitalic_z, the phase transition that gives rise to the GIN and the GOUT has not yet taken place.

What is most interesting, though, is the evident trade-off between Pmsubscriptğ‘ƒmP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ptsubscriptğ‘ƒtP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that can be seen in parts (b) and (c) of the figure. Clearly, under the constraint that Pnsubscriptğ‘ƒnP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is roughly the same for both probabilistic and heuristic flooding, for zğ‘§zitalic_z larger than approximately 2.52.52.52.5, Pmsubscriptğ‘ƒmP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is significantly larger for probabilistic flooding than it is for heuristic flooding. On the other hand, Ptsubscriptğ‘ƒtP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is significantly larger for heuristic flooding across practically all the spectrum of zğ‘§zitalic_z values that Figure 5 encompasses.

But notwithstanding this trade-off, FigureÂ 5 also suggests that the two types of flooding become more and more similar to each other as zğ‘§zitalic_z is increased. In fact, as the nodesâ€™ degrees become larger and GğºGitalic_G more homogeneous (approaching, in the limit, the complete graph on nğ‘›nitalic_n nodes), the heuristic function of (2) approaches a small constant and heuristic flooding progressively becomes probabilistic flooding.

The corresponding results for graphs with degrees distributed according to a power law are shown in the plots of Figure 6. Once again, our strategyâ€™s effectiveness is corroborated by part (a) of the figure. Also, parts (b) and (c) reveal the same trade-off between Pmsubscriptğ‘ƒmP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ptsubscriptğ‘ƒtP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that we observed in the Poisson case, along with a similar tendency, especially in the case of part (b), for the two algorithms to resemble each other as Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ is increased toward 3333. The justification for part (b) is that, at these values for Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, heuristic flooding has a small value for Pnsubscriptğ‘ƒnP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (cf.Â part (a)), one that can be achieved by probabilistic flooding with a value of pğ‘pitalic_p for which Pmsubscriptğ‘ƒmP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT remains relatively low. As for part (c), increasing Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ toward its higher values makes the occurrence of nodes of very high degree ever less likely. Consequently, heuristic flooding no longer refrains so strongly from sending the information being broadcast to the high-degree nodes of the network. This makes path lengths tend to lean toward those of probabilistic flooding.

But what is especially noteworthy in the power-law case is that the superiority of heuristic flooding in terms of Pmsubscriptğ‘ƒmP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT becomes very pronounced as Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ is decreased from roughly Ï„=2.5ğœ2.5\tau=2.5italic_Ï„ = 2.5. This happens because, under a power law, the graph tends to contain a large set of nodes of small degree, many of them of degree 1111. In order to reach the same number of nodes as heuristic flooding, probabilistic flooding must run with a value for pğ‘pitalic_p that is near 1111, which causes an unnecessarily high number of messages to be sent. Heuristic flooding, in turn, is relatively insensitive to the plethora of low-degree nodes, since it attempts to provide each and every node with the same probability of receiving the information.

7 Conclusions

Flooding a network probabilistically for information dissemination is an attempt at reducing the heavy communications demand that uninformed flooding incurs in terms of how many messages are needed. The drawback, of course, is that the guarantee of network-wide information delivery may be lost. In this paper we started with the recently introduced probabilistic flooding, in which every node forwards the information to all of its neighbors with constant probability.

Then we introduced an alternative technique, called heuristic flooding, which employs degree-based probabilistic decisions at the nodes, aiming at a pre-defined probability, the same for all nodes, that a node receives the information being disseminated. We have also contributed a detailed mathematical analysis of both probabilistic flooding and heuristic flooding, comprising analytical predictions of the techniquesâ€™ reachability, their communications requirements, and an indicator related to the time needed for completion of the flooding.

Our extensive simulation results have revealed the two techniquesâ€™ main characteristics on random graphs with Poisson- and power-law-distributed degrees. They have also indicated an excellent agreement between theory and experimentation in most cases.

In addition, one final set of simulations designed especially to allow a meaningful comparison between the two flooding techniques demonstrated an interesting trade-off involving them: in general, heuristic flooding outperforms probabilistic flooding in terms of communications requirements, but the opposite holds in terms of the delay required for completion. Curiously, the balance between the two sides of this trade-off is not equally tipped: for example, under a power law with relatively small parameter, the communications-related gain of heuristic flooding over probabilistic flooding significantly surpasses its delay-related loss.
